intro: Fagara pterota var. guarantica, commonly known as the Guianan arrowroot, is a species of flowering plant in the family Berberidaceae. It is native to the tropical regions of South America, particularly in countries like Guyana, Suriname, and French Guiana. The plant is characterized by its stout, tuberous roots, which are used as a starchy food source by indigenous communities. Its leaves are typically large, elliptical, and have a smooth or slightly hairy surface. The flowers are small and clustered, often greenish-white in color, and appear in the axils of the leaves.
